title: Pro Log: Nairo Quintana returns to Movistar, Tour de France routes revealed, Demi Vollering and Jonas Vingegaard win Vélo d’Or
content:
Cyclist
Pro Log: Nairo Quintana returns to Movistar, Tour de France routes revealed, Demi Vollering and Jonas Vingegaard win Vélo d’Or

Welcome back to another edition of Pro Log. As the road cycling season winds down, the transfers and contract extensions ramp up.

Ineos Grenadiers has been busy, with 18-year-old American cyclist AJ August turning professional with the squad on a three-year deal. Ben Swift has signed a new two-year contract, and Laurens De Plus has extended for three years. Carlos Rodríguez has also re-signed until the end of 2027.

Results powered by FirstCycling.com

Elsewhere, Jasper Philipsen (Alpecin-Deceuninck) beat Mark Cavendish (racing under ‘Legends’ and not his Astana-Qazaqstan team) in a sprint finish at the Tour de France Prudential Singapore Criterium on 29th October.

Related Posts

Mark Cavendish delays retirement to race for one more year in 2024

Tour de France Femmes 2024 route announced ft. Alpe d’Huez and a mini Monument

UCI bans use of painkiller Tramadol from 1st March

Men’s Tour de France 2024 route announced: What will riders face on the road from Florence to Nice?

1. Nairo Quintana signs one-year contract with Movistar

𝗡𝗮𝗶𝗿𝗼 𝗤𝘂𝗶𝗻𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗮 𝘃𝘂𝗲𝗹𝘃𝗲 𝗮 𝗰𝗮𝘀𝗮

Confirmamos que @NairoQuinCo formará parte de la plantilla de #MovistarTeam2024.

https://t.co/evwPQCjsQg pic.twitter.com/9hjHnWzFaG

— Movistar Team (@Movistar_Team) October 28, 2023

Nairo Quintana has signed a one-year deal to return to Movistar. Quintana last rode professionally for Arkéa-Samsic, but they parted ways after his Tour de France disqualification in 2022.

The 33-year-old was disqualified from the 2022 Tour de France – in which he finished 6th on GC – following a positive test for Tramadol. He was the first cyclist to be sanctioned for doing so.

Tramadol is an opioid painkiller whose side effects can include dizziness. A 2017 survey conducted by the UCI revealed that 68% of urine samples containing Tramadol – taken from across 35 Olympic sports – were from cyclists. While not a banned substance on the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) list at the time, Tramadol was still prohibited by the UCI. As the World Anti-Doping Agency has recently approved Tramadol to be on its list of prohibited substances from 2024, riders can now face a four-year suspension if they test positive.

Movistar confirmed the signing of Quintana with a press release that reads: ‘Quintana returns… after his first spell from 2012 to 2019, years in which he turned into a beacon and representative for Latin America, well beyond cycling and sports in general.’

2. Tour de France routes announced

The routes for the 2024 Tour de France and Tour de France Femmes races were unveiled in Paris. The men’s peloton will depart from Florence, Italy, and cover 14 gravel sectors and 52,230m of elevation gain on the way to Nice.  

That’s right – a reminder that the men’s Tour de France will not finish on the Champs-Élysées next year due to the Olympic Games also being held in Paris. Instead, the three weeks will culminate with a 34km individual time-trial from Monaco to Nice. 

For the first time in three years, the 2024 Tour de France Femmes will host a foreign Grand Départ, with the race kicking off in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. The peloton will then head from the Netherlands into Belgium for a mini-mixture of Amstel Gold and Liège-Bastogne-Liège, before hitting French soil on Stage 4. 

A mountainous final weekend awaits. Stage 7 marks the longest day in the saddle at 167km as Stage 8 finishes with a dramatic ascent of Alpe d’Huez.  

3. Vollering and Vingegaard win Vélo d’Or award 

Demi Vollering and Jonas Vingegaard win the Vélo d'Or awards for 2023. Based on scores from an international panel of journalists, Vollering got 171 points, ahead of Kopecky (139) and Van Vleuten (99). Vingegaard got 142 points, Van der Poel (133), Pogačar (126) pic.twitter.com/NUcWA0Jwzg

— the Inner Ring (@inrng) October 24, 2023

Demi Vollering (SD Worx) and Jonas Vingegaard (Jumbo-Visma) won the Vélo d’Or awards for 2023. Created in 1992 by Vélo magazine, the award honours the season’s best cyclists as determined by a jury. The women’s Vélo d’Or has only been in existence since 2022. 

Vollering topped the Women’s WorldTour standings in 2023, successfully completing the Ardennes Classics triple (Amstel Gold Race, Flèche Wallonne and Liège-Bastogne-Liège) as well as a thrilling overall victory at the Tour de France Femmes. Vingegaard also won the Tour de France ahead of Tadej Pogačar, with general classification victories in Gan Camiño and the Critérium du Dauphiné. 

4. Jasper Philipsen wins Tour de France Prudential Singapore Criterium 

The exhibition event of the Tour de France Prudential Singapore Criterium may not be an official race, but Jasper Philipsen counts it as win number 20 of the season.  

Racing 20 laps on a 3km circuit, the peloton included riders such as Tadej Pogačar, Mark Cavendish, Chris Froome, Peter Sagan and Jonas Vingegaard. An attack from Pogačar (of course) was reeled in 26km from the finish where Philipsen launched his powerful sprint. Cavendish finished second with Pogačar completing the podium.
